Abbreviations are used for nematode and nematomorph genera in the Results and Discussion section of this work, as well as in all phylogenetic trees. Abbreviations are listed below. This kingdom is comprised of over one million species, which are placed into two major groups: 47,000 species are vertebrates, while the remainder are invertebrates.

The metazoa have been divided into three groups, the mesozoa, parazoa, and eumetazoa (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . Metazoans which possess no true tissue layers are classified as mesoszoa and parazoa. Those with true tissue layers are eumetazoa, a group that is separated into two groups on the basis of body construction. Diploblastic eumetazoa possess two germ (tissue) layers, an outer ectoderm and an inner endoderm.
Triploblastic eumetazoa are characterized by a third germ layer, the mesoderm, which lies between the ectoderm and endoderm.

Triploblasts can be subdivided based upon the presence or absence of a fluidfilled body cavity called a coelom (Ruppert, 1991) . Acoelomates have no coelom; their mesoderm consists of a mass of tissue between the gut and body wall. Eucoelomates possess a true coelom, surrounded by a thin layer of mesoderm-derived cells called the peritoneum (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . This peritoneum effectively separates the internal organs from the coelom. Coelomate animals are further divided into two major groups, protostomes and deuterostomes. Developmental differences distinguish these two divisions (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . While protostome eggs divide by spiral cleavage, deuterostome eggs display radial cleavage. In protostomes, the blastopore eventually becomes the mouth, while in deuterostomes, this opening is fated to become the anus. l The coelom in protostomes is formed through the hollowing out of the mesoderm (schizocoely); the deuterostome coelom arises from the pinching off of gut diverticula (enterocoely). Brusca and Brusca (1990) recognize seven phyla as deuterostomes:

Chordata, Hemichordata, Echinodermata, Chaetognatha, and the lophophorates (Phoronida, Ectoprocta, and Brachiopoda) . The remaining coelomate phyla, including such taxa as Annelida, Arthropoda, and Mollusca are recognized as protostomes. The "traditional" grouping of taxa described here is depicted in Figure 1 . Recent molecular evidence (Mackey, et al., 1996) indicates that the lophophorates are protostomes, allied with molluscs and annelids; subsequendy, these animals have been placed with other protostomes a grouping called the Lophotrochozoa (Figure 2 ).

A third group of metazoa possess a false body cavity (pseudocoelom) which is neither mesodermally-derived nor surrounded by a peritoneum. The internal organs of these animals are free within the fluid of the body cavity. Such animals are known as pseudocoelomates.
The classification "pseudocoelomate" encompasses nine diverse animal phyla:

Gastrotricha, Rotifera, Acanthocephala, Priapulida, Kinorhyncha, Lorcicifera, Entoprocta, Nematomorpha, and Nematoda (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . To date, there is much debate on how these phyla should be placed into the overall evolutionary scheme of the animal kingdom. The classical view, taught in many general biology and zoology courses, presents a monophyletic origin of the pseudocoelomates (see Figure 1 ). Monophyly, according to Lorenzen (1983) is a condition in which several species arise from a single "stem species." Viewed in this manner, the pseudocoelomates are often grouped together into a taxon collectively known as the Aschelminthes. Ruppert (1991) gives only two requirements for inclusion into this taxa: the presence of a pseudocoelom and a cuticle. Hyman (1951) considers Aschelminthes to be a phylum and all the pseudocoelomate taxa to be classes, while others take the Aschelminthes to be a superphylum. However the taxon Aschelminthes is interpreted, it suggests close evolutionary relationship among all pseudocoelomates.

A newer idea is that the pseudocoelomates are polyphyletic, arising from two or more immediate ancestors (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . Several lines of evidence support this theory. A molecular study by Winnepenninckx et al. (1995) indicated three major groups (clades) of pseudocoelomates, each arising from a different ancestor. A morphological study by Wallace et al. (1996) Winnepenninckx, et al., 1995, and Aguinaldo, et al. 1997) . Aguinaldo et al. (1997) showed a close relationship of nematodes to arthropods. These findings effectively eliminate the "Aschelminthes" grouping, and place the pseudocoelomates throughout the tree, notably among the protostomes ( Figure 2 ).

Between 12,000 and 15,000 species of nematodes (Nemata) have been identified (Brusca and Brusca, 1990 and Maggenti, 1981) , making this phylum second in number only to the arthropods (Fitch, et al., 1995) . Nematodes, which are nonsegmented, pseudocoelomate roundworms, are an incredibly diverse group: they can be free-living or parasitic, and can be found in nearly every environment on the planet. Physical size of nematodes varies from a few millimeters to over a meter in length (Lambertsen, 1985, Khan and Jairajpuri, 1994) ; most freshwater nematodes rarely exceed 1 cm in length (Poinar, 1991) . Sexes are usually separate, but hermaphroditic nematodes have been documented. Poinar (1991) discusses some freshwater nematodes which reproduce by parthenogeneis.

All nematodes feature a body plan of triploblastic construction, surrounded by a protective, five-layered cuticle (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) , which covers the entire exterior of the animal. The cuticle is secreted by a thin layer of underlying tissue called the hypodermis (Poinar, 1991) . Poinar (1991) indicates the presence of specialized structures (e.g., setae and bristles) on the cuticles of some freshwater species, which aid in morphological classification. The pseudocoelom of a nematode is not spacious (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) ; internal organs occupy much of the coelomic space. Nervous and excretory systems in nematodes, as well as longitudinal muscles are well-developed, while respiratory and circulatory systems are rudimentary (Poinar, 1991) . The nervous system consists of several connected ganglia, including a cerebral ganglion. Nematode excretory systems can be of two types: an excretory duct and gland located ventrally, or a tube-like system of excretory canals, running longitudinally (Poinar, 1991) .

Several sensory organs are present in all nematode species. Their presence, absence, and morphology forms the basis for morphological classification (Lorenzen, 1994 , Poinar, 1991 . Tactile chemoreceptors known as amphids, which are paired, lateral organs extending from the cuticle, are located near the anterior of the animal. In some species, they are located within the ring of anterior sensory papillae on the nematode's head (Poinar, 1991) . Exact amphid structure varies among taxa (Lorenzen, 1994) . Some nematode genera possess phasmids, caudally located sensory organs generally considered to be chemoreceptors (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . Lorenzen (1994) considers phasmids to be less significant in a biological sense than the amphids. The presence or absence of these organs, along with the characteristics of the amphids, has played a significant role in the development of nematode morphological taxonomy.

Free-living nematodes have simple life cycles; more complex life cycles are observed in parasitic genera. The life cycles of all nematodes consist of six stages, during which they undergo four molts of the cuticle. Nematodes hatch from eggs whose shells contain chitin, and progress through four "juvenile" stages before the mature adult form is attained (Poinar, 1991) . Since no significant change in morphology is discernible during the juvenile stages, these phases are generally not referred to as larvae, though some authors choose to employ the term. Rhabditid nematodes develop completely in approximately 3-5 days; under optimal conditions, while other freshwater namatodes mature in approximately 1-6 weeks (Poinar, 1991) .

Of the nematodes, Malakhov (1994) states, "[they] are an unusually uniform group of animals in the morphological sense." This uniformity has led to weakly defined classification systems at the lower (i.e., order and family) levels (Maggenti, 1991) .
Several conflicting nematode taxonomies are shown in Figure 3 . Maggenti (1981) ,

whose nematode taxonomy is widely accepted, utilized several characteristics to establish his classification scheme. Some of these characteristics were the size, shape, and position of the amphids, the presence or absence of other sensory organs (i.e., phasmids) and the presence or absence of somatic setae. The morphology of the "lip" region was also a determining factor in his analysis. Maggenti considered the ecological situations of the various groups, deemed an important characterizing factor by Croll and Matthews (1977) , to separate the nematodes into two classes, Adenophorea and Secementea. The absence of phasmids is the basis for the placement of a given species within Adenophorea; in contrast, members of Secementea possess phasmids. According to Maggenti (1981) , Class Adenophorea encompasses both free-living and parasitic nematodes which inhabit marine, freshwater, and terrestrial environments. Members of Class Secementea are almost exclusively terrestrial (Maggenti, 1981) . Croll and Matthews (1977) accept the two-class taxonomy, though they recognize significantly fewer orders than does Maggenti, and they also divide Phylum Nematoda into Adenophorea and Secementea. 1977; Maggenti, 1981; Malakhov, 1994) . Lorenzen (1983) reviews several earlier taxonomic systems which recognize the two-class system, as well as other classification schemes (notably Andrassy, 1976) which he rejects, that divide the phylum into three classes. Andrassy (1976 ( , reviewed by Lorenzen, 1983 divides Adenophorea into two groups, which Lorenzen believes are homologous enough to each warrant equal ranking with Secementea. Malakhov (1994) , who considers "Nematoda" to be a class, cites Enoplia, Chromadoria, and Rhabditia as subclasses within "Nematoda" rather than within "Adenophorea" or "Secemetea," which he does not recognize. Interestingly, Malakhov (1994) traditional phylogenetic methods of phenetics and cladistics, which rely solely upon morphological data as their basis for classification. In phenetics, one examines as many characters as possible from different organisms to determine their relatedness; evolutionary consequences are largely ignored (Brusca and Brusca, 1990) . Cladistics is arguably a somewhat better classification method, as its basis is common ancestry (Coomans, 1983) . Groups of organisms are said to be related if they share common derived characteristics. Characters must be homologous (traceable to some common ancestor) rather than analogous (having similar structure and/or function but not traceable to some common ancestor) to be considered valid in cladistic analysis (Lorenzen, 1983 and Coomans, 1983) .

Classical phylogenetic methods are difficult to apply to nematodes; their generally small size prevents the identification of phylogenetically significant characters. Coomans (1983) states that disagreements as to the importance of certain characters are not uncommon in nematode classification. When applying cladistics to the nematodes (or other pseudocoelomates), analogous characters can be can be mistaken for homologous ones (Turbeville et al., 1992) . Clearly, another method must be employed to obtain a reliable taxonomy for the nematodes and for the pseudocoelomates in general. Since the mid-1960s (reviewed by Li, 1997) and the advancement of molecular biology, a trend has developed in which phylogeny, and hence evolution, can be studied from a molecular standpoint.

The genes encoding ribosomal RNA (rRNA) are arranged in a distinct pattern on eukaryotic nuclear chromosomes. Since each transcription event yields only one copy of the gene product (Singer and Berg, 1991) , the rRNA genes are present in multiple copy numbers on the chromosomes, forming long tandem arrays. The abundance of such genes allows for large amounts of product to be produced quickly. The genes coding for 18S, 5.8S, and 28S rRNAs are arranged in that order on the chromosome, as shown in Figure 5 . The eukaryotic 28S gene is approximately 4000 nucleotides long, and is referred to as a large subunit rRNA; the 18S gene measures approximately 1800-1900 nucleotides in length, and is referred to as the small subunit (SSU) rRNA (Winnepenninckx, et al. 1994) . The genes are separated ( Figure 5 ) by two noncoding regions called internal transcribed spacers (ITS 1 and 2, Hillis and Dixon, 1991) , which vary in length among species. Another noncoding region, the external transcribed spacer (ETS), is located-upstream of the 18S gene. A nontranscribed spacer (NTS) separates adjacent arrays. The three genes and three transcribed spacers make up a single RNA polymerase I transcriptional unit (Singer and Berg, 1991) , which is separated from other units by a non-transcribed spacer (NTS, Figure 5 , Hillis and Dixon, 1991 ).

The location, copy number (per haploid genome) and size of the transcriptional unit can greatly vary among species (reviewed by Singer and Berg, 1991) . Humans may possess between 150 and 200 copies of a 14 kb transcriptional unit on chromosomes 12, 11 14,15, 21, and 22. In contrast, the genome of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has 55 copies of a 6 kb transcriptional unit on chromosome 1. Since the size and sequence of the rRNA genes themselves show little interspecific variation, the difference in size of the entire unit may be attributed to a variation in the lengths of the spacers (Singer and Berg, 1991) .

The phenomenon of unequal crossing over between nonallelic tandem repeats is thought to affect rRNA genes in several ways. Unequal crossing over may account for the increase and decrease in rRNA transcriptional unit copy number (reviewed by Singer and Berg, 1991) . This results in individuals of the same species possessing different numbers of copies, and a variation in rRNA gene copy number in a given individual's somatic cells over that individual's lifetime. From an evolutionary standpoint, unequal crossing over, as well as gene conversion, is thought to contribute to the phenomenon of concerted evolution, in which all rRNA genes in an individual evolve at the same rate (Hillis and Dixon, 1991) . This results in all rRNA genes being identical.

The 18S rRNA gene product folds into a distinct, stem-and-loop secondary structure (DeRijk et al., 1992) . The secondary structure is composed of approximately sixty helices of varying size. Figure 6 depicts the secondary structure model for the 18S rRNA gene of the snail, Onchidella celtica (Winnepenninckx et al., 1994) , employing the helix numbering system proposed by DeRijk et al. (1992) . Compensatory mutations between paired nucleotides have been found to maintain the integrity of the secondary structure over time, despite the continuous evolution of the primary sequence (Hillis and Dixon, 1991) .

The study of evolutionary relationships using techniques involving molecular biology and statistics is known as molecular phylogenetics or systematics (reviewed by Li, 1997) . Molecular phylogeny uses corresponding positions on nucleotide sequences as characters, as opposed to physical characteristics. The presence of an A, C, G, or T 13 residue at a given position is understood as a character state (Swofford and Olsen, 1990 ).
The basis of this type of study is the analysis of nucleotide substitution over time (Li, 1997 ).

Molecular phylogenetic methods offer several advantages over more traditional morphological techniques such as phenetics and cladistics. Nei (1987) points out that gene sequences evolve on a more regular basis than do morphological characteristics,

while Li (1997) cites the suitability of molecular data to statistical analysis as an advantage. Molecular data is also more abundant; it can be used to devise phylogenies for microbes and small eukaryotes (such as nematodes and other pseudocoelomates)

which possess few distinguishing morphological characters. Li (1997) does, however, caution that molecular phylogenetics is subject to its own set of errors; the "ideal" phylogenetic analysis is one which synthesizes morphological and molecular data.

The substitution of one nucleotide at one site may take millions of years to occur (Li, 1997) . Thus, sequences analyzed using molecular phylogenetics are those thought to evolve from a common ancestor. Analysis of the number and frequency of substitutions among a group of sequences allows for the computation of divergence times and the construction of phylogenetic trees. As multiple substitutions at a given site are likely to occur over evolutionary time, models have been proposed to correct for these "multiple hits" (Li, 1997) . Most molecular phylogenetic studies, and the computer programs designed to aid in them, employ two models (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) . The first is the Jukes and Cantor one-parameter model (Jukes and Cantor, 1969; reviewed by Li, 1997 ).
Using this model, it is assumed that all nucleotides are present in a DNA sequence with equal frequency and that all substitutions are equally likely (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) .
A third assumption is that all sites evolve at the same rate (Li, 1997) .

Another frequently-used model is Kimura's two-parameter model (Kimura, 1980;  reviewed by Li, 1997) . This method takes into account the observation that substitutions do not occur randomly, that transitions (purine/purine or pyrimidine/pyrimidine substitutions) occur more often than do transversions (purine/pyrimidine substitutions and vice versa). Assumptions inherent in this model are an equal frequency of all nucleotides, and independent rates of transition and transversion events.

Other, more complex substitution models, including the Tajima and Nei threeparameter model, in which nucleotides can be present at different frequencies. All models, no matter how complex, are based upon the assumption of uniform rates of substitution at all sites. Li (1997) indicates that a statistical algorithm known as the gamma distribution can be applied to the models to correct for this assumption. Li (1997) shows that more parameters do not necessarily imply a more realistic model, as more assumptions need to be made with each new parameter. Also, statistical sampling error, inherent in a finite data set such as a nucleotide or amino acid sequence, increases with the addition of parameters.

Before a molecular phylogenetic tree can be constructed, an alignment of all sequences being analyzed must be performed. Alignments are required since molecular phylogenetic studies require not only molecular homology, but also positional homology (Swofford and Olsen, 1990 ) among all considered taxa. That is, a given position in one sequence must correspond to the same position in all other sequences.

In addition, an alignment must take into account that insertions and deletion mutations have occurred over time, as well as smaller point mutations. As it is nearly impossible to distinguish an insertion from a deletion in phylogenetic analyses (Li, 1997) Editor (DCSE) and Clustal V (Higgins et al., 1991) enable multiple alignments of many sequences to be generated. The DCSE package (DeRijk, 1993) can also be used to construct secondary structure alignments. After manually aligning sequences, the user can employ established secondary structure models, to effectively "map" the secondary structure of a given gene. Li (1997) cautions that effective multiple alignments require that sequences be fairly similar to one another and possess few insertions and deletions. Swofford and Olsen (1990) review several algorithms used by alignment software.

Among these are sequence similarity algorithms (e.g., that of Needleman and Wunsch, 1970 ) which maximize the number of matched bases, and sequence distance algorithms, which minimize the number of mismatched bases. Both types assign a "gap penalty" to each insertion or deletion. Thus, the "best" alignment is the one with the fewest gaps. In some cases, gaps of all sizes are given equal weight; in others, larger gaps are weighted heavier than smaller ones (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) .
At the heart of molecular phylogeny is the phylogenetic tree, which is a graphic representation of the evolutionary relationships among organisms or groups of organisms.

A phylogenetic tree consists of several components. The taxa being studied are often referred to as operational taxonomic units, or OTUs (N ei, 1987) . The topology, or branching pattern of the tree depicts phylogenetic relationships. External nodes form the "leaves" of the tree and represent OTUs, while internal nodes are positioned at branching points (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) . In some types of phylogenetic trees, branch length is interpreted as the degree of divergence (represented by the number of nucleic acid substitutions) which have occurred in species since their branching. Nei (1987) discusses several classifications of phylogenetic trees. In a rooted tree, the topology is "rooted" with an organism which is believed to share a common ancestor with all OTUs. Most phylogenetic analyses, however, involve the generation of unrooted trees. These trees do not show the common ancestor, emphasizing solely the relationships among various OTUs (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) . A species tree depicts the evolutionary pathways taken by the various OTUs; a gene tree traces the pattern of divergence followed by a single gene obtained from different species. A gene tree and a species tree generated from the same OTUs will not necessarily possess the same topology (Nei, 1987) .

When constructing unrooted trees, an outgroup is usually selected and added to the data set to provide a link to the remainder of the "tree of life" (Weston, 1994 ). An outgroup can be comprised of single animals or multiple taxa, which have been shown to branch prior to the taxa being studied (the ingroup, Swofford and Olsen, 1990) . For example, Aguinaldo et al. (1997) , when studying the phylogenetic position of nematodes, utilized representatives of the earlier-branching phyla Cnidaria and Echinodermata as outgroups. Swofford and Olsen (1990) (Woese, 1987) . Trees are created through analysis of the functional relationships among distance values (Li, 1997) .

The simplest distance matrix method is known as Unweighted Pair-Group Method with Arithmetic Mean (UPGMA). This method of tree construction, while simple, is based upon the assumption of evolutionary rate constancy among all lineages (Li, 1997) .

To construct a tree using UPGMA (Nei, 1987) , pairwise evolutionary distances are computed from aligned sequences using rate correction algorithms such as the Jukes and Cantor model; these distances are then arranged into a matrix. The two OTUs possessing the smallest distance between them are combined into a composite OTU. A new matrix is constructed with this new unit, and the process is continued until all OTUs have been linked into a tree. Saitou and Nei (1987) describe a newer distance method known as the neighbor joining (NJ) method. NJ is based upon the principle of minimum evolution; its objective is to find the tree with the shortest length, reflecting the least evolution. The NJ method has several merits over other distance matrix methods: it does not assume a constant evolutionary rate for all OTUs, it is applicable to any type of evolutionary distance data, and it provides evolutionary branch length as well as tree topology. An NJ analysis begins with all OTUs arranged in a starlike "tree," which assumes no clustering of taxa.

After a distance matrix is created, all possible pairs are analyzed. The two OTUs which yield the smallest sum of branch lengths are joined as "neighbors," forming a composite OTU. This OTU is then joined with a third, provided this joining minimizes total length.
The process is continued until all OTUs are considered.

Maximum parsimony methods are among the most widely used techniques for phylogenetic reconstruction (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) . They follow the rules of parsimony, which suggest that the simplest solution to a given problem is the correct one.

Parsimony methods consider each position in an alignment separately. The "true" tree is the most parsimonious tree; that is, the tree which infers the least number of evolutionary "steps" (i.e., substitutions) over time (Nei, 1991) .

In a maximum parsimony analysis, only phylogenetically "informative" sites are taken into consideration. Li (1997) defines informative sites as those sites which favor some evolutionary pathways over others. Li (1997) reviews a general method adapted by Fitch (1977) which applies parsimony methods to nucleotide sequence data. From informative sites, all possible trees are created, and the total number of inferred substitutions from each tree is summed.

The tree with the smallest number of substitutions is taken to be the correct tree. Unlike distance methods, more than one "most parsimonious" tree can be obtained from any given analysis (Nei, 1987) . Nei (1991) indicates that maximum parsimony methods may be more accurate than distance methods when the number of nucleotides being studied is 19 large. The situation is reversed, however, when the number of substitutions per site is large.

Though each treemaking method has its advantages, Li (1997) cautions that no single method is applicable to all circumstances. A thorough phylogenetic analysis makes use of several methods. Nei (1987) indicates that phylogenetic trees generated by any method are prone to two major classes of error: topological error and branch length error. Topological error results in a tree displaying a branching pattern different from that of the "true" topology. In molecular phylogenetic trees, branch length errors lead to false estimations of the number of nucleotide substitutions which have occurred since OTUs branched.

Regardless of the method used to construct it, any phylogenetic tree must be tested for statistical validity after it has been constructed. Felsenstein (1985) proposed the application of the statistical bootstrap test to evaluating evolutionary confidence levels, specifically, to the determination of monophyly in a clade. Since then, bootsrapping has become one of the most widely-used tests of phylogenetic validity. The method works well with any treemaking method, and is well-suited for the analysis of large numbers of taxa (Li and Gouy, 1990 ).

In bootstrap tests, data sets are randomly resampled to create a given number of new data sets of the same length (reviewed by Li, 1997) . At least one hundred replicates of the original data set are usually taken. Trees are constructed from each new data set;

the proportion of trees in which monophyly is supported for a given clade is presented as a confidence interval at the appropriate node on the original tree (Li, 1997) . Felsenstein (1985) suggests accepting a hypothesis of monophyly only if the confidence level is 95% 20 or higher. Hillis and Bull (1993) indicate that a bootstrap value of 70% or higher corresponds to a 95% confidence level that a given clade is genuine; bootstrap values lower than 50% are considered insignificant.
Several requirements have been established (Felsenstein, 1985) for bootstrapping.

Each character must be independent of all others, the treemaking method must present a good estimate of the actual topology, and the data set must be representative of the larger population. Rodrigo (1993) indicates that these requirements have lead to error and bias in bootstrapping analyses. Bootstrapping does not take into account covarience of characters or unequal rates of evolution among OTUs; the method often rejects monophyly when it is true.

Other methods for estimating the confidence of phylogenetic trees exist. Like the bootstrap method, jackknifing (reviewed by Swofford and Olsen, 1990 ) involves randomly resampling the original data set. In a jackknife test, each sampling sequentially eliminates one or more characters; trees built from this method result from data sets of ever-decreasing size. The distance matrix approach (Li and Guoy, 1990) does not test the significance of entire phylogenies. Rather, this method is used to test the significance of intemodal distances by studying their variance. Nei (1992, 1993) describe the standard error test, which can be employed to test the confidence in the (Rzhetsky and Nei, 1993) . A zero branch length indicates an invalid branch.

Ribosomal RNA Genes and Phylogenetic Study Woese (1987) cites three properties which molecules should possess in order to be useful in molecular phylogenetic studies. First, the molecule should exhibit "clocklike behavior," that is, its sequence should be as randomly-changing as possible. Second, the molecule should be present in a wide range of organisms, so effective phylogenetic studies over a broad spectrum of life can be carried out. Finally, the molecule should have a relatively large size for a number of reasons: statistics are more reliable with larger sized molecule, and a random change at one position is less likely to affect other positions in larger mlecules. Winnepenninckx et al. (1994) review several factors which make the ribosomal RNA genes (in particular small subunit genes such as 18S) favorable for such studies.

The genes are large, and contain much "phylogenetic information." They are suitable for study over a broad taxonomic range, as 18S genes are present in all eukaryotes, and their sequences consists of alternating highly-variable and more highly-conserved regions.

Such conservative regions allow for the construction of "universal" primers for molecular study. This property also allows the genes to be arranged into multiple alignments with relative ease (Swofford and Olsen, 1990) . Hillis and Dixon (1991) point out that small subunit rRNA genes are among the slowest evolving of all genes studied in eukaryotes, though rapidly-evolving enough to generate usable data. They also point out that concerted evolution of multiple copies of these genes facilitates phylogenetic studies, in that it greatly reduces the potential for intraspecific heterogeneity, allowing smaller sample sizes to be studied for the accurate characterization of a species.

Several groups (reviewed by Dixon and Hillis, 1993) have indicated that the compensatory mutations necessary to maintain the secondary structure of 18S and other rRNA gene products may compromise the randomly-changing nature which is vital to a sequence used in molecular phylogenetic studies. These studies suggest that stem bases (characters) should either be deleted from analyses or weighted differently than loop bases. However, Hillis and Dixon (1993) , in a study employing 28S rRNA sequences from a "traditional" phylogeny of vertebrates, showed that the closest estimation of the "true" phylogenetic tree was obtained when both stem and loop characters were utilized.
Their conclusion was that both stem and loop characters contain useful phylogenetic information, and that the weighting of stem characters should be reduced by no more than 20% in practical analysis.

One drawback to the use of rRNAs for phylogenetic analysis is that, although the genes are generally slowly-evolving, they may change more rapidly over time in some species than in others. This property has created some confusion in the determination of the phylogenetic placement of the nematodes within the metazoa (Aguinaldo, et al., 1997) .

Cladistic studies (Backeljau, et al., 1993; Schram, 1991) have shown the nematodes to occupy a basal position to other bilateral animals, branching prior to the protostome-deuterostome bifurcation. A similar position was found in a molecular study by Winnepenninckx, et al. (1995) which employed 18S rRNA gene sequences. The analysis presented in this study utilized available nematode 18S gene sequences,
including those from Caenorhabditis elegans, Pellioditis typica, and Nematodirus battus.
A subsequent analysis (Aguinaldo, et al., 1997) revealed that these sequences were rapidly evolving.

For one analysis in their study, Aguinaldo's group (1997) position as they had in previous studies (Aguinaldo, et al. 1997, Figure 7a) . When a second analysis was carried out (Figure 7b ), this time using only the slowly-evolving sequence from Trichinella along with slowly-evolving sequences from representatives of other phyla, the nematodes grouped with the protostomes, forming a clade with arthropods and other molting animals. Because of this unique trait shared by all its members, this group was subsequently labeled the Ecdysozoa.
A thorough, molecular analysis of phylogenetic relationships within Nematoda has yet to be performed. A recent study (Fitch, et al. 1995)

The phylogenetic position of the phylum Nematoda among the metazoa has been shown with some confidence in the recent work of Aguinaldo, et al. (1997) . However, the phylogenetic relations within the phylum remain disputed (Malakhov, 1994; Maggenti, 1983) . The present work is aimed at analyzing the relationships among the various nematode orders using molecular data. To do this, the 18S rRNA gene of representatives from two nematode orders were sequenced: Diplolaimelloides represents the order Monhysterida (Subclass Chromadoria), and Adoncholiamus represents Enoplida (Subclass Enoplia). These sequences were analyzed along with sequences obtained from representatives of other orders, which are either the products of previous work in this laboratory (Garey, unpublished data), or are available from GenBank. Neighbor-Joining trees were constructed using the Molecular Evolutionary Genetics Analysis (MEGA) 25 software package (Kumar, et al., 1993) ; Felsenstien's (1995) Phylogenetic Inference Package (PHYLIP) was employed in the construction of Maximum Parsimony trees.
Plate cultures of E. coli which contained the 18S rRNA gene of Diplolaimelloides and Adoncholaimus in the pMOS blue phagemid were kindly provided by Paul deLey of the University of Gent, Belgium.

Plasmid DNA was isolated using the alkaline lysis miniprep procedure described by Ausubel et al. (1994) . After plasmid-containing bacteria from the original plate cultures failed to grow in Luria-Bertani/ampicillin (LB/ampicillin) broth (500 ml containing 5g tryptone, 2.5 g yeast extract, 2.5 g NaCl and augmented with 25 pi 0.25 mg/ml ampicillin), loopfuls of cells was placed into 1.7 ml microcentrifuge tubes containing 1.5 ml TE buffer; these tubes were microcentrifuged for one minute at 13,000 rpm. The supernatant was decanted, and the pellet of cells was resuspended in alkaline lysis buffer (50 mM glucose, 25 mM tris pH 8, 10 mM EDTA) containing 4 mg lysozyme. After the suspension was mixed with a NaOH/SDS solution (25 mM NaOH, 1.25% SDS), and the cells were incubated at room temperature for five minutes. To precipitate chromosomal DNA (and thus separate it from plasmid DNA), 150 pi 3M potassium 5M acetate solution (100 ml contains 60 ml 5M KAc and 11.5 ml glacial acetic acid) was added. After a five-minute microcentrifugation, the supernatant was transferred to a fresh microcentrifuge tube.

To purify plasmid DNA prior to precipitation, a single phenol/ phenol:chloroform/chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (24:1) extraction was carried out on each preparation. Following this, 2 volumes of 100% ethanol were added to the aqueous phase for precipitation, and left on ice 20 minutes. The precipitation mixture was then microcentrifuged for 10 minutes. The supernatant was discarded, and the resulting pellet of plasmid DNA was washed in 250 pi 70% ethanol, and centrifuged for 5 minutes, after which the supernatant was discarded. The pellets were dried in a Savant vacuum drier at 45°C, and resuspended and frozen in 50 pi RNase TE (3 pi RNAse in 1000 pi TE buffer).
Miniprep products were visualized on 0.8% agarose minigels. Ten microliters of miniprep products were added to five pi gel loading buffer (50% w/
v glycerol, 2% v/v
50X TAE, lOmM EDTA, 0.05% bromophenol blue), and run using lpg of a HinDTH/EcoEl cut of phage X (Promega, Madison, WI) as a molecular weight standard.
Approximate DNA concentrations were determined through comparison of band intensity of the miniprep products with that of the markers.

A standard chemical transformation procedure was used to transform plasmid DNA into calcium-competent E. coli DH5a cells (Ausubel et al., 1994) . Competent cells were first thawed, then 200 pi were placed into glass plating tubes along with enough plasmid DNA for a final concentration of 1/10 pg. Tubes were placed on ice 40 minutes, after which they were placed in a 42°C water bath for 2 minutes. Three dilutions of cells, 150 pi, 20 pi, and 2 pi, were plated onto prewarmed LB-agar plates supplemented with 0.25 mg/ml ampicillin. To each dilution was added 50 pi 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl-p-D-galactopyranoside (X-gal), 10 pi isopropylthiogalactoside (IPTG) inducer, and enough deionized water to bring the final volume to 200 pi. Plates were covered, and incubated overnight at 37°C.

Following incubation, colonies containing transformed cells were identified by a white appearance on the plates, indicating disruption of the lac operon (Brock et al., 1994) . Some of these colonies were subcultured onto LB/ampicillin agar plates, while others were inoculated into tubes containing LB/ampicillin broth for further purification.

Overnight broth cultures (10 ml each) were prepared from white colonies obtained after transformation. A second round of alkaline lysis minipreps was performed on transformed DH5a cells to obtain pure plamid DNA. Plasmid DNA was further precipitated using the polyethylene glycol (PEG) precipitation protocol described by Ausubel et al. (1994) . Two minipreps were combined for approximately 80-100 pi of product. A single phenol/phenol rchloroform/chlorform.TAA extraction was carried out upon each sample, resulting in approximately 60-80 pi of recovered aqueous phase.

Following the guidelines suggested in the Applied Biosystems (The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, Foster City, CA) Chemistry Guide, 0.16 volumes 5M NaCl and 1 total volume of 13% PEG (13% PEG 8000 in water) was added to each sample. Following a 20-minute incubation on ice, samples were precipitated with two volumes 100% ethanol and microcentrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 20 minutes at 4°C. Ethanol was removed, and pellets were washed and microcentrifuged with 250 pi 70% ethanol. DNA was then vacuum dried, and each pellet was resuspended in 20 pi deionized water.
Approximate DNA concentration was determined on 0.8% agarose minigels as described previously, this time employing at most five microliters of sample mixed with 1.5 pi GLB.

Transformed cells containing inserts from each organism were cultured in 10 mL LB/ampicillin broth overnight at 37°C with shaking. Eight hundred fifty pL of this culture was mixed with 150 pL 15% glycerol. These suspensions were frozen at -80°C.

Cesium chloride preparations (Ausubel et al. 1994) were carried out on plasmid DNA from Diplolaimelloid.es and Adoncholaimus as alternatives to post-transformation minipreps and precipitation with PEG, for higher yields of plasmid DNA at greater concentrations. Use of this method allowed for multiple sequencing runs to be performed from a single preparation.

Approximately 100 pi of transformed cells from the glycerol suspensions were used to inoculate 10 ml of LB/ampicillin broth. These were incubated overnight at 37°C with shaking. Subsequently, 1 ml of these cultures was used to inoculate 1000-ml flasks containing 500 ml LB broth and 1000 pi 0.25 mg/ml ampicillin. These were incubated for 8 hours at 37°C with shaking. When cells had reached logarithmic growth phase To obtain plasmid DNA, a crude lysate preparation similar to the alkaline lysis miniprep procedure was performed. Cell pellets were completely resuspended in 4 ml glucose/tris/EDTA solution (50 mM glucose, 25 mM tris, 10 mM EDTA), and transferred to plastic, 40 ml centrifuge tubes. Cells were lysed during a 10-minute room temperature incubation in GTE and 1 ml lysozyme solution (25mg/ml lysozyme in 25 mM tris pH 8).

To separate chromosomal from plasmid DNA, 10 ml NaOH/SDS (0.2 M NaOH, 1% SDS) was added to the tubes. The mixture was stirred until it became clear and viscous, after which it was incubated on ice for 10 minutes. Subsequent addition of 7.5 ml 3M

potassium acetate solution, pH 4.8 (3M potassium acetate, 6.3% formic acid) resulted in a white precipitate of chromosomal DNA after 10 minutes' incubation on ice. The tubes were centrifuged at 4°C at 13,000 rpm for 10 minutes, using a Sorvall SS-34 rotor. The supernatant (containing plasmid DNA) was transferred to another 40 ml plastic centrifuge tube. Supernatants were poured through several layers of cheesecloth to trap unwanted chromosomal DNA and other particulate matter.

Approximately 13.5 ml (0.6 volumes) of isopropanol, which had been saturated with 5M NaCl, was added to the supernatant, which was mixed by inversion prior to a 5 minute incubation at room temperature. In the SS-34 rotor, the mixture was centrifuged at 24°C at 11,500 rpm for 10 minutes. The supernatant was discarded, leaving a pellet of plasmid DNA, which was washed in 70% ethanol and centrifuged in the SS-34 rotor at 30 24°C at 11,500 rpm for 10 minutes. After the ethanol was drained, the pellet was vacuum-dried for 10 minutes at 45°C.

In preparation for ultracentrifugation, the pellet was resuspended and mixed in a solution consisting of 8 mL TE buffer, 8.8 grams solid cesium chloride, and 0.8 ml 10 mg/ml ethidium bromide. The suspension was transferred into an 11 ml ultracentrifuge tube. Ultracentrifugation was carried out in a Beckman (Fullerton, CA) XL-70 ultracentrifuge. Samples were centrifuged at 50,000 rpm for 20 hours at 20°C in a Beckman 70.1 Ti rotor.

After ultracentrifugation, a band of plasmid DNA was clearly visible using long wave UV light. This band was extracted and transferred to an 11 ml plastic centrifuge tube using an 8-guage needle attached to a 2 cc tuberculin syringe. Extraction was done carefully, avoiding any particulate matter or chromosomal DNA, which formed a second band higher in the CsCl density gradient.

To obtain pure plasmid DNA, ethidium bromide was removed via a series of extractions with isopropanol (saturated with 5M NaCl), until the aqueous layer (containing the plasmid DNA) was clear. Aqueous layers were brought up to 8 ml total with deionized water and transferred into 40 ml plastic centrifuge tubes.

Plasmid DNA was precipitated from aqueous phases through overnight precipitation at -20°C with 1/10 volumes 3M sodium acetate solution (pH 4.6) and two total volumes 100% ethanol. The next day, the mixture was centrifuged at 4°C at 10,000 rpm for 10 minutes in the SS-34 rotor. Ethanol was decanted, and the pellet was washed in 70% ethanol, and vacuum-dried for 10 minutes. Each pellet was resuspended in 1000 pi TE buffer, and the DNA was precipitated with 1/10 volume NaAc and two total volumes 100% ethanol. Pellets were washed with 70% ethanol, vacuum dried ,and resuspended in 200 pi TE buffer.

DNA concentration was measured using a Shimadzu model UV-1201S digital ultraviolet spectrophotometer. A 1:20 dilution of the DNA was prepared in a quartz cuvette using 50 pi post-cesium chloride product added to 950 pi TE. An absorbance reading at 260 nm (the maximal UV absorbance for DNA) was taken. To screen for possible protein contamination of the DNA, the 260 nm:280 nm absorbance ratio was measured spectrophotometrically. 280 nm is the maximal absorbance for protein; acceptable levels for this ratio fall within the range of 1.8 to 2.0 (Ausubel et al. 1994) .

With the A260 reading, the DNA concentration could be calculated. The dilution factor (20) was multiplied by A260 reading and 50 pg/ml (concentration of DNA at 1.0 absorbance). This equation yielded DNA concentration in pg/ml, which was converted to pg/pl. If the concentration was above 0.2 pg/pl, 50 pi of the product were diluted to this concentration for use in cycle sequencing reactions (see subsequent discussion).

The 18S rRNA genes from Diplolaimelloides and Adoncholaimus were sequenced using a dye-based labeling system and automated sequencing. The gene was sequenced in fragments of two large, overlapping pieces, 18S45 and 18S12A. Cycle sequencing primers, designed relative to conserved sequences from the human 18S rRNA gene, were used to sequence regions of approximately 300-450 bp. The positions of the primers relative to the human 18S rRNA gene are shown in Figure 8 . The nucleotide sequences of these primers are given in Appendix A. Sequences generated from the primers, when assembled using the AutoAssembler software package (The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, Foster City, CA), overlapped to create a contiguous sequence in both directions.

Once purified plasmid DNA had been obtained, dye-labeled fragments to be used for sequencing were generated using the Perkin- Cycle sequencing reactions were carried out in a Perkin-Elmer (Foster City, CA)
GeneAmp model 2400 thermal cycler. The cycler was set to run 25 cycles under the following parameters: 96°C denaturing for 10 seconds, between 40°C and 48°C
annealing for 5 seconds, and 60°C extension for 4 minutes. Samples were held at 4°C until use.

Extension products from cycle sequencing reactions were purified using ethanol precipitation to minimize the potential of interference from unincorporated dye terminiators in subsequent automated sequencing. For each reaction, a 1.7 mL microcentrifuge tube was prepared, containing 50 pi 100% ethanol and 2 pi sodium acetate, pH 4.6. The entire 20 pi of cycle sequencing products were added, and the tubes were vortexed and incubated on ice for 20 minutes. Tubes were microcentrifuged at 13,000 rpm for 30 minutes, ethanol decanted, pellets washed twice in 70% ethanol, and vacuum dried.

Each pellet was suspended in 25 pi template suppression reagent (TSR, The Perkin-Elmer Corportation, Foster City, CA) to stop any further extension. Samples were vortexed and pulsed, then heated in a temperature block set at 95°C for two minutes for denaturing. Samples were again vortexed and pulsed, after which the entire 25 pi volume was transferred to Genetic Analyzer tubes (The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, Foster City, CA) specifically designed for the Applied Biosystems (ABI) model 310 genetic analyzer.
Samples were vortexed and pulsed once again, and placed at -20°C until sequencing.
Samples were loaded into the ABI 310 Genetic Analyzer for sequencing.

Sequencing runs were carried out for 100 minutes each. Briefly, the sequencer operates by automatically injecting a small amount of cycle sequencing product into a 4 mL capillary tube filled with separating gel. Extension products are electrophoresed through this tube. A laser, projected through the capillary, excites the incorporated dye labels to fluoresce at specific wavelengths. The sequences of the fragments are elucidated from the relative positions of the incorporated dyes. Electropherograms generated by the analyzer can be used to indicate the reliability of data obtained from a given run.

Once sequencing runs for all the 18S primers had been completed, sequences were transferred onto floppy disks and loaded into Applied Biosystems' AutoAssembler program for assembly. This program generated a contiguous sequence in both directions from the sequence fragment data obtained from primers. The program also allowed electronic comparison of the electropherograms obtained from individual primers, which enabled manual resolution of sequence ambiguities and discrepancies among individual primer sequences.

In some cases, accurate sequences could not be generated from some of the 18S primers shown in Figure 8 . In these cases, custom primers were designed and obtained from Gibco BRL (Grand Island, NY). Nucleotide sequences for custom primers used are given in Appendix A.

Custom primers arrived in anhydrous form and were resuspended in 300 pi deionized water, and concentrations were determined spectrophotometrically, using the molecular weight of each primer, which was provided by Gibco BRL. Primers were first diluted to 10 pM, then 8 pi aliquots of these dilutions were mixed with 92 pi of deionized water for a final working concentration of 0.8 pmol.

After consensus sequences for Diplolaimelloides and Adoncholaimus were generated using AutoAssembler software, the sequences were put into an appropriate format and loaded into the DCSE (Version 2.60) alignment file containing previously published nematode sequences from representatives of various nematode orders, as well as unpublished sequences obtained in this laboratory. DCSE was used first to manually align the sequences, then to adjust the alignment based upon secondary structure characteristics (DeRijk, 1992, Figure 6 ), including stems and loops.

The nematode sequences contained in the completed secondary structure alignment was used to generate phylogenetic trees. A list of nematode species used in phylogenetic tree construction, as well as the order (sensu Maggenti) represented by each is presented in Table 1 (see Results) . The 18S rRNA gene sequence of the nematomorphs Chordodes morgani and Gordius aquaticus were included in the alignment; at least one of these taxa is present in all analyses as an outgroup.

Aligned sequences were manually edited into the format required by the MEGA program (Kumar et al., 1993) , which was employed to generate phylogenetic trees using the Neighbor-Joining method (Saitou and Nei, 1987) . Jukes and Cantor's one-parameter sequence substitution model, as well as and Kimura's two-parameter model, were used to construct Neighbor-Joining trees. To assess the robustness of Neighbor-Joining trees, one hundred bootstrap replicates of the original data set were used in all analyses. MEGA was also used to perform the standard error test on Neighbor-Joining trees, which generated confidence probability (CP) values.

The PHYLIP Version 3.572c software package (Felsenstein, 1995) was used to generate maximum parsimony trees. After a data set in the appropriate format was constructed, the DNAPARS option within PHYLIP was employed to build single-pass maximum parsimony trees. The SEQBOOT option was then used to create one hundred bootstrap replicates of the original data set; DNAPARS was again employed to create a most-parsimonious tree from each of the replicates. Finally, the CONSENSE option was used to build a bootstrapped, majority-rule and strict consensus tree from each of the 100 replicate-based parsimony trees. Using CorelDRAW 6.0, PHYLIP trees were manually redrawn to match, as closely as possible, the order of taxa observed in the Neighbor-Joining trees.

Plasmid DNA preparation and automated sequencing methods were successful in generating two new nematode sequences in both directions. A 1719-nucleotide sequence was obtained from Adoncholaimus, and a 1923-nucleotide sequence was obtained for
Diplolaimelloides.

In general, cesium chloride preparations yielded more favorable results than did minipreps, as more sequencing reactions could be performed from a single cesium chloride preparation than could be carried out from several mini-preparations. Table 1 .

For most analyses involving phylogenetic tree construction, a trimmed alignment was created in which the first 190 positions of each sequence, as well as the final 657 positions (including gaps and nucleotides) were removed, as data was missing in these positions for some taxa. This left an alignment of 4808 positions, with 2066 positions containing nucleotides. The alignment, presented in MEGA format, is shown in Appendix B.
From the secondary structure alignments, it was determined that nematode 18S

rRNA sequences are generally well-conserved. Notable regions of significant variance occur, however, in regions such as "E23" and E43" (DeRijk, 1992 and Figure 6 ). Other significant variation was observed within helices 6, 10, E10-1,43, and 49. Variance was also observed in several of the "loop" regions between helices. When compared to 18S

sequences from other eukaryotes in the original alignment, it was observed that entire helices in the "E23" and "E43" variable regions were absent in most nematode sequences. From the trimmed (4808-position) MEGA data set, a new data set was created for maximum parsimony analysis in PHYLIP. This data set consisted of 1309 positions (all of which were nucleotides), no gaps, and no sites with missing data. Of the 1309 sites, 737 sites were parsimony-informative; these sites were used by PHYLIP for analysis.

A single pass of the initial data set generated one maximum parsimony tree of 1809 steps; this tree is shown in Figure 10 . This tree was in agreement with the A majority-rule and strict consensus tree, generated from the analysis of 100 bootstrap replicates of the PHYLIP data set, is shown in Figure 11 . Bootstrap values less than 50% are considered insignificant and have been omitted from the tree. The tree has a similar topology as the single-pass parsimony tree; monophyly of Chromadoria and the Figure 10 . Maximum Parsimony tree generated by a single pass of the original data set. Branch lengths are not indicative of evolutionary distance. All nematode classifications are sensu Maggenti (1981) . Figure 11 . Majority rule and strict consensus tree inferred by analysis of maximum parsimony data. Branch lengths are not indicative of evolutionary distance. Numbers at the forks represent the number of times out of 100 bootstrap replicates that a group consisting of the taxa to the right of that fork occurred. Bootstrap values less than 50% are not shown. All nematode classifications are sensu Maggenti (1981) .

In both Neighbor-Joining ( Figure 9 ) and Maximum Parsimony (Figures 10 and   11 ) trees, veiy strong support is given to the position of Order Monhysterida (represented by Diplolaimelloides) branching along the same lineage as that which gave rise to the Secementea. In NJ analysis, the position of Diplolaimelloides was maintained in one hundred trees, each constructed from an individual replication of the original data set. In parsimony analysis, 97% bootstrap support is given to this position.

Two possible deductions regarding Monhysterida's placement and the origin of the Secementea can be made from these data. If Maggenti's (1981) taxonomy is to be observed, then Monhysterida is an order within Class Adenophorea. In the case of this analysis, Monhysterida (and Subclass Chromadoria) is observed to be the Adenophorean order most closely associated with the Secementeans. Under this assumption, Subclass Chromadoria is the sister taxon to the Secementea as a whole.

A second hypothesis is that Subclass Chromadoria should be included within Class Secementea. Adamson (1987) proposed such a classification scheme, wherein Subclass Chromadoria and Subclass Monohysteria (analogous to Maggenti's Order Monhysterida) were placed within Class Rhabditea (roughly equivalent to Secementea). Adamson (1987) rejects the "Adenophorea" classification on the grounds that it is paraphyletic. He also suggests that characters used to differentiate Adenophorea form other nematodes are ancestral characters, and not indicative of any special phylogenetic relationships (Adamson, 1987) . If Monhysterida is to be included within Secementea, bootstrap support for the grouping of Enoplida as a sister taxon to the Secementeans is less than 50% in parsimony analysis. Insignificant bootstrap support is given in NJ analysis for a common lineage among the Enoplida/Trichocephalida clade and the Secementea.

Both hypotheses support the idea that the Secementea did not arise concurrently with the Adenophorea. If Diplolaimelloides is understood to be an Adenophorean, both the Neighbor-Joining tree (Figure 9 ) and the Maximum Parsimony trees (Figures 10 and   11 ) indicate paraphyly of Adenophorea; at least three branching events occurred within Adenophorea prior to the radiation of the Secementea. The assumption that Diplolaimelloides represents a Secementean order reduces each number of bifurcations to two. No tree supports an initial separation of Adenophorea and Secementea from an "archi-nemata," as hypothesized by Maggenti (1983, Figure 4a ).

The NJ tree (Figure 9 ) trees offer only weak support for the monophyly of Adoncholaimus (Enoplida) with Trichocephalida (less than 50% bootstrap levels, but slightly higher CP values). The single-pass MP tree ( Figure 10 ) and the strict-consensus tree (Figure 11 ) both show Enoplida branching after a Mermithida/Trichocephalida clade, 47 but prior to Monhysterida. Like the NJ tree, the strict-consensus tree (Figure 11 ) offers only weak support for the relative position of Enoplida. Malakhov (1994) indicates that, within Subclass Enoplia, Order Enoplida is taken to be the most primitive. His phylogeny (Figure 4b ), which indicates paraphyly within Enoplia, shows other orders (i.e., Trichocephalida and Mermithida) branching after Enoplida, following Enoplia's initial divergenece from Chromadoria. The primitive nature of Enoplida is not supported by molecular data. NJ analysis (Figure 9 ) indicates that the first nematode order to branch is Mermithida (represented by Me. nigrescens), followed by the sister taxa Enoplida and Trichocephalida. Parsimony analysis shows an initial branching of a Mermithida/ Trichocephalida clade, followed by Enoplida. Weak support is given to the position of Enoplida after these orders in both types of analysis.
In both NJ and MP analysis, two major clades are found within the Secementea.

The first clade, depicted at the top of all trees, is a clade encompassing the orders Rhabditida, Strongylida, and Diplogasterida. The second is a clade encompassing Ascaridida and Spirurida. NJ analysis groups Tylenchida with the second clade, albeit with weak support.

An unexpected result is observed within the Rhabditids. Fitch et al. (1994) found strong support for the monophyly of the Rhabditis and Rhabditella species with the Caenorhabditis species in a grouping known as the "Eurhabditids." Although both Maggenti (1983) and Malakhov (1994) blumi. A CP value of 97% was obtained for this grouping in NJ analysis. In both analyses, 100% bootstrap support (with a 99% CP) is given to the monophyly of this clade with the Caenorhabditis species. When Strongylida is grouped with Rl. axei and R.

blumi, monophyly of the latter two species is weakened. Rhabditis/Rhabditella monophyly is given 80% bootstrap support (84% CP) in NJ trees, and only 55.8% support in MP trees. When a Neighbor-Joining analysis of the trimmed data set was performed which excluded N. brasilensis (Figure 12 ), bootstrap confidence in Rhabditis/Rhabtidella monophyly rose to 98%, and Rhabditid topology matched that favored by Fitch, et al. (1994) . The CP value for Rhabditis/Rhabditella monophyly rose dramatically from 84% to 99%. Similar results were obtained when a MP tree was constructed which excluded N. brasilensis (Figure 13 ). In this case, monophyly of the Rhabditis and Rhabditella species was given 88.5% support.

In all analyses, Order Diplogasterida is shown to be a sister taxon to Rhabditida. Support for this arrangement is slightly stronger in NJ analysis (96% bootstrap support for monophyly) than in MP analysis (91% bootstrap support). A second major monophyletic clade observed within the Secementea unites the orders Ascaridida and Spirurida as sister taxa. Close association of Ascaridida and Spirurida is indicated by Malakhov (1994) , while Maggenti (1981) Figure 11 ). NJ analysis provides weak (<50%) support that this order may be monophyletic with the Ascaridida/Spirurida clade. Though weakly supported, the latter placement increases confidence in the monophyly of this clade with the Rhabditida/Diplogasterida clade, a grouping supported by Malakhov's (1994) phylogeny.

Such placement also eliminates polyphyly within Secementea, unless Monhysterida is taken to be a Secementean order. Though Malakhov (1994) indicates close association between Rhabditida and Tylenchida, results of the present analysis are supported too weakly to support or refute this association.

At the level of subclasses, Maggenti's (1981) inclusion of Ascaridida within Rhabditia seems inaccurate, as this would make the taxon polyphyletic. The molecular data seems to better corroborate Malakhov's (1994) scheme, in which Ascaridida and Spirurida are sister taxa, while "Rhabditida" is placed distantly from this grouping.

Similarly, Maggenti's (1981) Subclass Diplogasteria is shown to be polyphyletic in this analysis; orders Tylenchida and Diplogasterida are shown on both MP and NJ trees to arise along different lineages.

One advantage of the present study over similar phylogenetic analyses is the method of alignment employed. Manual alignments which take secondary structure into account (Winnepeninckx, et al., 1994 ) may be considered more reliable than automated alignments which do not. Secondary structure alignments offer more assurance of positional homology than do alignments which only consider primary structure.

This study is not, however, without its own set of limitations. First, considering the enormity of the taxonomic group under consideration, the data set is small, resulting in the exclusion of a great deal of pertinent phylogenetic information. This may be partially responsible for weak support for several of the phylogenetic relationships depicted on the trees. Second, all analyses were based solely upon comparisons of 18S rRNA gene sequences. Although results from previous morphological studies were consulted during analysis for the purpose of corroboration, an exhaustive molecular phylogenetic study should compare data obtained from more than one molecule. Gene sequences for nuclear 28S rRNA, as well as mitochondrial 16S rRNA have been widely used to complement 18S data, and have been used independently for phylogenetic study.

Molecular evolutionary studies are often prone to errors due to unequal substitution rates effects, which may lead to long branch lengths and possibly inaccurate topologies on trees generated by distance methods. It has been established (Aguinaldo, et al., 1997 ) that the substitution rates of some nematode 18S rRNA genes are approximately 2 to 3 times greater than those of other metazoa. This was seen to compromise the study performed by Winnepenninckx, et al. (1995) ; long branch lengths were observed for the nematodes used in the analysis, creating a basal position for the phylum. Although both slowly-evolving (e.g., Trichinella) and rapidly-evolving (e.g.,

Caenorhabditis species) were used in this analysis, unequal rate effect did not appear to act as a compromising factor. In NJ trees, the length of the longest branch (that of Tu. muris) is observed to be only approximately two times as long as the shortest nematode branch length (that of Me. nigrescens). Several of the branches (e.g., those leading to Diplolaimelloides, M. arenaria, D. lethieri, and the Caenorhabditis species) have similar lengths.

This study contributed two new nematode 18S rRNA sequences to a growing database of other nematode 18S sequences. Both of these sequences represent orders from which representative sequences had not previously been available.

In the present study, fifteen of these sequences were used to generate a partial molecular phylogeny of several nematode orders, by creating a secondary structure alignment, and using this alignment to generate Neighbor-Joining and Maximum Parsimony trees. The study supports some aspects of the current, morphology-based nematode classification schemes, while indicating that others aspects warrant reappraisal:

(1) Order Monhysterida (represented by Diplolaimelloides) was shown to branch just prior to those nematodes recognized by Maggenti (1981) as Secementeans, with a high level of confidence. This may lend support to Adamson's (1987) inclusion of Subclass Chromadoria within the Secementea.

(2) Contrary to Malkhov's (1994) taxonomy, molecular data indicates that Enoplida (represented by Adoncholaimus) may not be a basal order; Orders Mermithida is observed branching prior to Enoplida on all trees. Support for such a conclusion, however, is weak.

(3) The data appears to support the theory of Adamson (1987) that Adenophorea, if recognized as a valid taxon, is paraphyletic. Several branchings events of Adenophorean orders are observed prior to the radiation of the Secementea.
(4) The subclasses Rhabditia and Diplogasteria (sensu Maggenti, 1981 ) appear polyphyletic in this anlaysis; representatives of Rhabditia appear in two Secementean clades.

Gaps are inserted manually or automatically until all homologous positions are arranged into columns on the data matrix. The simplest type of alignment is the pairwise alignment, which compares sequences from only two taxa. Software packages such as Genepro (Riverside Scientific Enterprises, Seattle, WA) can perform dot matrix analyses. FIGREF15.text: Elmer Corporation's (Foster City, CA) ABI Prism™ Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit with AmpliTaq®DNA Polymerase, FS. When sequencing plasmid DNA, approximately 250 ng of DNA was used, at a concentration of 100-500 ng/ml. When sequencing from miniprep preparations, between 4 and 6 microliters of DNA were used, at a concentration of approximately 160 ng/pl. Cycle sequencing reactions from cesium chloride preparations utilized two microliters of DNA which had been diluted to a concentration of 0.2 pg/pl. Cycle sequencing reactions were prepared in 0.2 ml Gene Amp thin-walled reaction tubes (The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, Foster City, CA). Each reaction consisted of 8 pi terminator ready reaction mix (A-, C-, G-, and T-Dye Terminators, dTTP, dATP, dCTP, dTTP, Tris-HCl pH 9, MgCh, thermostable pyrophosphatase, AmpliTaq DNA Polymerase, FS), 4 pi of a single primer at a concentration of 0.8 pmol, and the appropriate quantity of DNA. The reaction mixtures were brought to a final volume of 20 pi with deionized water. The mixtures were vortexed and briefly pulsed in a microcentrifuge.

FIGREF16.text: secondary structure alignment of fifteen nematode sequences (including Diplolaimelloides and Adoncholaimus) was created, which was 5656 positions in length (2266 positions contained nucleotides). Sequences from the nematomorphs Chordodes morgani and Gordius aquaticus were included as outgroups. Nematode and nematomorph taxa represented in the alignment, excluding Diplolaimelloides and Adoncholaimus, were (numbers of valid nucleotides in each sequence are in parentheses): Caenorhabditis vulgaris (1685), Caenorhabditis elegans (1760), Rhabditella axei (1684), Rhabditis blumi (1679), Meloidogyne arenaria (1788), Mermis nigrescens (1745), Nippostrongylus brasiliensis (1686), Toxocara canis (1717), Trichinella spiralis (1779), Trichuris muris (1836), Dirofilaria immitus (1732) Diplogaster lethieri (1744), Ascaris suum (1742), Gordius aquaticus (1796), and Chordodes morgani (1783). FIGREF17.text: bootstrap values were obtained when the Jukes and Cantor model was employed (results not shown). The Neighbor-Joining tree (Figure 9) moderately supports monophyly of the Secenenteans. Two major Secementean clades are observed. Strong support is given to the branching of all Secementeans from the same lineage as Subclass Chromadoria (represented by Diplolaimelloides), which, in this analysis, appears to be the closest Adenophorean relative to the Secementeans. Neighbor-Joining analysis offers weak support for the position of Enoplida (represented by Adoncholaimus) as the sister order to Trichocephalida (represented by Tn. spiralis and Tu. muris). Order Mermithidia (represented by Me. nigrescens) is observed to be the most basal nematode group, branching immediately after the nematode/nematomorph bifurcation. The Adenophorea as a group appear paraphyletic (i.e., some, but not all, members of the group arose from a single common ancestor). In Neighbor-Joining analysis, N. brasiliensis, placed by Maggenti (1981) into Order Strongylida, unexpectedly finds strong support for placement among the members of Order Rhabditida (R. blumi, Rl. axei, and the Ceanorhabditis species). FIGREF18.text: Neighbor-Joining tree (Figure 9) in most respects. Notably, the relative position of Diplolaimelloides is preserved. The tree differs from NJ trees in that Enoplida and Trichocephalida are no longer sister taxa; Enoplida now branches after a monophyletic clade encompassing Trichocephalida and Mermithida. The monophyletic clade encompassing the Secementean orders Ascaridida, Spirurida, and Tylenchida is maintained, as well as the position of Diplolaimelloides with respect to the Secementea.

FIGREF19.text: origin of the Secementea. In this case, NJ analysis suggests that the Secementea may have arisen along the same lineage as the Enoplida/Mermithida clade. Parsimony analysis would indicate a common lineage for Enoplida and the Secementea. Both conclusions are open to debate, however, as support is weak for such assumptions.

FIGREF20.text: indicated a close relationship between Rhabditida and Strongylida, moderate to strong support is given in the present analysis to the inclusion of Strongylida (represented by N. brasilensis) within Rhabditida. Woese (1987) briefly reviews two commonly-used methods for constructing phylogenetic trees: distance matrix and maximum parsimony. The former method considers each sequence as a whole, and is used to analyze the differences among aligned sequences to estimate evolutionary distance

TABREF9.text: Secementeans as a whole is strongly supported. Support for Trichocephalida/Mermithida monophyly is weak, as is support for the branching of Enoplida just prior to Monhysterida. Support for the positioning of N. brasilensis among the Rhabditida is given moderate (74.3%) bootstrap support, however, monophyly of R. blumi and Rl. axei is questionable, as this grouping is given low (55.8%) support. Tylenchida (represented by M. arenaria) is observed in this tree to branch prior to all other Secementea.
